name: Thoracic Outlet Syndrome with Venous Compression
chief_complaint: My arm swells and turns blue when I raise it, and I feel a constant ache in my shoulder
physical_findings: positive Adson's test (loss of radial pulse with arm maneuvers)
distended superficial veins on affected side

lab_results.Venous Doppler ultrasound: shows compression of subclavian vein with arm abduction

treatment: First rib resection via transaxillary approach
Botulinum toxin injection to scalene muscles in select cases
prognosis: Good with surgical intervention (80-90% symptom resolution), though may require prolonged physical therapy post-op
description: Compression of the neurovascular structures (particularly subclavian vein) between the clavicle and first rib, often exacerbated by anatomical variations or repetitive overhead activities. The venous variant presents with positional venous obstruction and potential thrombosis.
risk_factors: Poor posture with forward head position
Presence of cervical rib (extra rib above first rib)
multiple_choice: Thoracic Outlet Syndrome with Venous Compression
